question.text: Why do you think you’re making a difference on Climate Change?

answer.text: First up, it’s pretty simple math.  In the last 3 months, we offset 66 tonnes of CO2.  That’s a big offset - big enough to reduce all our clients' emissions to be in line with the Paris Accord.  Or for a more visual impact - on a yearly basis each one of our members took 5 cars off the road.

We take security very seriously. Very very seriously. So seriously, people are warned before we arrive at parties to not ask us about it...
Don't believe us? Check out just how far we go...
We employ a multi-layered approach to ensure your account has complete security.

First, your account and it's value are secured on the blockchain, meaning that the same security that protects over $17 trillion of assets also protects your account. This security is, in practical terms, unhackable.

Second, for the data we absolutely must store - and there is some - it’s stored by Google. Instead of trying to create our own security (and risking getting it wrong) - we pay Google to do it for us. And we trust google to do that well. But - data breaches do happen, and big companies do occasionally make mistakes. So...

Third, we have adopted a unique method for storing the key to your assets that means we never store the actual account details. Unlike other financial institutions, our setup means that even if Google's servers were hacked, and the bad guys could do whatever they wanted to our databases - they -still- wouldn't be able to access your account (they'd make a mess to our internal accounting though, so we're pretty determined to keep them out).

Fourth: We actively watch our clients accounts for strange activity, and because of our unique designs we have some pretty good methods for catching it. After all, our best protections can't stop someone's laptop getting stolen. In these cases, we are building an automatic fail-safe, which will automatically trigger to keep your funds completely safe.

question.text: Are you just as safe as a regular bank?

answer.text: So in this case, the simple answer is "Yes". Everyone who deals with money is required, by law, to not lose any of it, and someone keeps watch over us to make sure we follow the rules.  We have to follow the standard regulations that every company that deals with money has to follow - watching for suspicious transactions, doing frequent internal audits, tracking every transaction to ensure it goes to the right person, and other such jobs.

However, because we are a non-profit, we have additional requirements that nobody else has. We are required by law to have a regular audit from an outside company, and to be completely transparent with our clients. Anyone who wants to can check our books to make sure every single penny goes to who it's supposed to.

We suspect if banks followed these rules, the rates of financial fraud in Canada would go way, way down. But we wouldn't suggest asking to see your banks books - there is a reason they don't want them public!

So this is a good start, but we are... well, we're pretty obsessed. So, we go way, way further. We run a live audit that ensures that - at every single minute of every day - everything is checks out. This is all done by our in-house software - because software never gets tired, never misses a transaction, and never does anything it hasn’t been told to.

At some points we still do have to have humans involved though, because even our software could have flaws.  We keep super-strict limits on who can access any account though, and our auditors are watching these people closer than anyone.  If something were to ever happen, we would know about it immediately, and know exactly who to talk to.

Why do we do all this?  Well, for one, an upstart company like ours has a lot to prove.  If we let through the rates of fraud and malpractice that happens at a regular bank, we’d be out of business in a heart-beat.  It’s more than this though.  All this waste and loss doesn’t need to happen.  It costs us $10 billion annually - that’s $350 for every Canadian, every single year.  If your 30 years old, it’s cost you over $10000 by now.  The tools exist to combat it, what’s missing is the willpower.  Some loopholes are just a legacy of old technology and processes, but sometimes the loopholes are more of a feature because closing them would impact some of the banks biggest money-makers.
We utterly refuse to compromise on any aspect of our business - we would never trade your security for profit.

TheCoin is a digital wallet that holds the digital currency of TheCoin. This acts as a chequing, savings and investment account in one. TheCoin currency itself is what is known as a stablecoin, meaning it avoids the volatility and uncertainty of other digital currencies.
What is a stablecoin, you may ask? It is a digital currency whose value is “pegged” (tied to) another asset or assets with its own intrinsic value, much like the gold standard of yesteryear.

question.text: How much will my money grow?

answer.text: Your money will grow alongside the stock market, meaning that on any given day, it can increase or decrease.  While we can’t promise a return on any single day, over the long term our investment strategy returns an average of 9.5% per year.  It’s even better when you work it out relative to regular interest.  When the bank pays you interest, it’s counted as income – and this means that you lose a big slice of it to the government immediately.  Our accounts use capital gains, which have many advantages to grow their value.  One is that it’s only charged ½ as much tax, so 9.5% in capital gains is the same as about 15% in bank interest.  On top of this, you only pay capital gains when you spend your money – which means your growth can be tax-free.

In concrete terms, you can expect your account size to double roughly every 7.5 years. If you started with $2000 on the day you were born, and didn't touch it for the next 65 years, you can reasonably expect around $1 million to be in your account at retirement. Of course, as you grow, we hope you can start saving a bit more, but that cool $million will certainly make retirement a lot easier.
